newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Peso move rattles regionals.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Peso move rattles regionals.

text.p: Southeast Asian currencies were thrown into a tailspin on Friday after the Philippines' shock move to effectively devalue the peso after repeated denials of such a step earlier in the week.
The Philippines Central Bank said at the start of trading on Friday it would allow the peso to trade in a wider range against the U.S. dollar, with immediate effect.
Dealers saw the move as the second de facto devaluation of an Asian currency in less than two weeks.
The peso sank over 11 percent to 29.450 to the dollar in immediate reaction to the news, before the Bankers Association of the Philippines halted peso-dollar trades for the day.
Dealers said the news, though widely seen an inevitable, did little to restore the already fragile confidence of investors and foreign fund managers in the region.
"They had very little choice anyway. It was just a matter of time, especially if all the stronger economies in this region are suffering. What else can they do," a Singapore dealer said.
In Thailand, the baht came in for another bashing just over a week after its own de facto devaluation, as the peso news spurred heavy demand for the dollar.
"It has definitely been hurt by the Philippine peso attacks. Speculators are focusing on both the Philippine and Thai currencies," a dealer at a Thai bank in Bangkok said.
The baht fell to a new low of 29.750 to the dollar in early trade against 29.100/29.200 late on Thursday. It was quoted at 29.900/29.950 in the onshore market and 29.350/29.450 offshore at 0415 GMT.
"We saw some bids for dollars at around 30.000 baht this morning," another Bangkok dealer said.
But dealers said the baht's weakness was contained by central bank measures, implemented when the currency came under speculative attack in mid-May, to block access to baht offshore.
"Offshore is still lingering behind because we don't have funds to push it with. It's difficult to push something you don't have the liquidity in," the Singapore dealer said.
But he added that the baht was looking weak. "People here are still seeing 32-35 (baht/dollar) levels whereas domestic is looking at 30-32," he said.
A Thai dealer said the baht weakness could also be attributed to high carried over commercial demand for dollars that was unmatched at the Thursday close.
Dealers said they had not detected any signs the Thai central bank had stepped in to defend the baht.
In Indonesia, the rupiah stopped sliding but remained weak as players began to re-evaluate the morning's developments.
"We see some dollar selling. I think offshore operators are taking profits as there is no problem with the rupiah," a European bank dealer in Jakarta said.
He said selling interest also seemed to be emerging in the swap market, which rose sharply on spillover from the peso.
"Some operators think we are in the same region, so it's better to cover first before anything happens, causing spot rupiah rates to decline and swaps to rise," another said.
"But after realising Indonesia has different economic fundamentals, they started to reverse positions," he said.
Spot rupiah was at around 2,435.5/36.5 at 0415 GMT against an early low of 2,437.0. It opened at 2,432.5/33.5.
The Malaysian ringgit also came under pressure but dealers said its downside was limited by a market already long dollars and signs of the central bank's presence.
Dealers said the ringgit was pushed down to a low of 2.4980 against the dollar but Bank Negara Malaysia was calling banks to check rates on the run up to that level.
"They've been around the whole day but they don't need to (act). Nobody's doing anything," the Singapore dealer said.
He said the ringgit's downside would be limited to 2.5050 to the dollar.
Further south, the Singapore dollar remained a relative island of calm, firming slightly as it ordinarily does on any signs of regional instability.
"There's not much interest on the dollar/Sing. It strengthened because when there's a crisis in the region, people will park their funds in Singapore," a dealer said.
But he added that there was little indication the Singapore dollar could strengthen beyond the 1.4280/1.4300 level to the U.S. dollar during the Asian session.
-- Syed Azman in Kuala Lumpur (603-206 2323), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221 384-6364), Vithoon Amorn/Anuchit Nguyen in Bangkok (662) 652-0642, and Sonali Desai in Singapore (65-8703090)
